newsitem.title: USA: Southern net declines on lower power sales.
newsitem.headline: Southern net declines on lower power sales.

text.p: Southern Co Wednesday reported a 19.7 percent drop in first quarter earnings, saying it came on a 1.3 percent decline in power sales.

"Mild weather in January, February and March of this year resulted in lower demand for electricity," chief executive A.W. Dahlberg explained. "Our acquisition of a stake in Consolidated Electric Power Asia also had some effect."
The interest in the Hong Kong electric utility was purchased from Hobewell Holdings.

Dahlberg said first quarter electricity use by retail customers in Southern's service area decreased 1.7 percent from a year earlier with in-home electricity needs down 9.7 percent to 8.8 billion kilowatt-hours.

Electricity consumption by commercial customers -- offices, stores and other non-manufacturing firms -- rose 0.3 percent to 8.7 billion kilowatt-hours. Industrial energy use increased 2.9 percent to 12.9 billion kilowatt-hours.
Total sales of electricity, including sales to other utilities, were down 1.3 percent in the latest quarter, Dahlberg said.
Southern, the largest proaucer of electricity in the United States, is the parent firm of Alabama Power, Georgia Power, Gulf Power, Mississippi Power and Savannah Electric.
In the three months ending March 31, 1997, the company earned $187 million or $0.28 a share, compared with $233 million or $0.35 a share for the comparable 1996 period.
First quarter 1997 revenues were $2.6 billion, compared with $2.4 billion in 1996's first quarter.
